a_0.formal problem:
theorem
fixes a b c d :: int
assumes h0 : "distinct [a, b, c, d]"
and h1 : "{a+b, a+c, a+d, b+c, b+d, c+d} = {10, 18, 19, 20, 21, 29}"
shows  "sorted [a, b, c, d] \<and> [a, b, c, d] = [4, 6, 14, 15]"
a_0.formal solution:
(* ### Problem
 Four distinct integers $a$, $b$, $c$ and $d$ have the property that when added in pairs, the sums 10, 18, 19, 20, 21, and 29 are obtained. What are the four integers in increasing order? (place a comma and then a space between each integer) The final Answer is 4,6,14,15
 ### Proof
 WLOG, let $a<b<c<d$. The smallest sum is $a+b=10$. The second-smallest sum is $a+c=18$. The second-largest sum is $b+d=21$. The largest sum is $c+d=29$. In summary, \begin{align}\tag{1} a+b&=10\\ \tag{2}
 a+c&=18\\ \tag{3} b+d&=21\\ \tag{4} c+d&=29 \end{align} There are two sums left, $a+d$ and $b+c$.
 We will break this problem into two cases, the first case in which the first of the two sums is smaller than the second, and the second case in which the first of the two sums is larger than the second.
 In the first case \begin{align} \tag{5} a+d&=19\\ \tag{6} b+c&=20 \end{align} Adding Equations (1) and (6) and subtracting (2), we have $(a+b)+(b+c)-(a+c)=10+20-18\Rightarrow b = 6$. Plugging this value into Equation (1), we find that $a+6=10 \Rightarrow a=4$.
 Plugging the value of $a$ into Equation (2), we find that $4+c=18 \Rightarrow c=14$. Plugging the value of $c$ into Equation (4), we find that $14+d=29 \Rightarrow d=15$.
 Thus, the four integers are $4,6,14,15$. In the second case, \begin{align} \tag{7} b+c&=19\\ \tag{8} a+d&=20 \end{align} Adding Equations (1) and (7) and subtracting Equation (2), we have $(a+b)+(b+c)-(a+c)=10+19-18 \Rightarrow b=5.5$.
 This case is impossible because $b$ is defined to be an integer.
 Thus, the only solution is $\boxed{4,6,14,15}$.
 *)

theorem
fixes a b c d :: int
assumes h0 : "distinct [a, b, c, d]"
and h1 : "{a+b, a+c, a+d, b+c, b+d, c+d} = {10, 18, 19, 20, 21, 29}"
shows  "sorted [a, b, c, d] \<and> [a, b, c, d] = [4, 6, 14, 15]"
 proof- 
  show ?thesis sledgehammer
a_0.informal problem: Four distinct integers $a$, $b$, $c$, and $d$ have the property that the sums of every possible pair of them are $10$, $18$, $19$, $20$, $21$, and $29$. Find the values of $a$, $b$, $c$, and $d$ in ascending order. The final answer is $4$, $6$, $14$, and $15$.

a_1.formal problem:
theorem
fixes a b c d :: int
assumes h0 : "distinct [a, b, c, d]"
and h1 : "{a+b, a+c, a+d, b+c, b+d, c+d} = {10, 18, 19, 20, 21, 29}"
shows  "sorted_list_of_set {a, b, c, d} = [4, 6, 14, 15]"

(* ### Problem

 Thus, the four integers are $4,6,14,15$. In the second case, \begin{align} \tag{7} b+c&=19\\ \tag{8} a+d&=20 \end{align} Adding Equations (1) and (7) and subtracting Equation (2), we have $(a+b)+(b+c)-(a+c)=10+19-18 \Rightarrow b=5.5$.
 This case is impossible because $b$ is defined to be an integer.
 Thus, the only solution is $\boxed{4,6,14,15}$.
 *)

theorem
fixes a b c d :: int
assumes h0 : "distinct [a, b, c, d]"
and h1 : "{a+b, a+c, a+d, b+c, b+d, c+d} = {10, 18, 19, 20, 21, 29}"
shows  "sorted_list_of_set {a, b, c, d} = [4, 6, 14, 15]"
 proof- 
  show ?thesis sledgehammer
a_1.informal problem: Four distinct integers, $a, b, c,$ and $d$, have the property that the set of their pairwise sums is $\{10, 18, 19, 20, 21, 29\}$. Find the sorted list of these four integers. The final answer is $[4, 6, 14, 15]$.

theorem
fixes a b c d :: int
assumes h0 : "distinct [a, b, c, d]"
and h1 : "{a + b, a + c, a + d, b + c, b + d, c + d} = {10, 18, 19, 20, 21, 29}"
shows  "sorted_list_of_set {a, b, c, d} = [4, 6, 14, 15]"

 Four distinct integers $a$, $b$, $c$ and $d$ have the property that when added in pairs, the sums 10, 18, 19, 20, 21, and 29 are obtained. What are the four integers in increasing order? (place a comma and then a space between each integer) The final Answer is 4,6,14,15

theorem
fixes a b c d :: int
assumes h0 : "distinct [a, b, c, d]"
and h1 : "{a + b, a + c, a + d, b + c, b + d, c + d} = {10, 18, 19, 20, 21, 29}"
shows  "sorted_list_of_set {a, b, c, d} = [4, 6, 14, 15]"
 proof- 
  show ?thesis sledgehammer
a_4.informal problem: Four distinct integers, $a$, $b$, $c$, and $d$, have the property that the sum of every pair of these integers is one of the following six numbers: 10, 18, 19, 20, 21, and 29. Find the four integers and list them in ascending order. The final answer is 4, 6, 14, and 15.

a_5.formal problem:
theorem
fixes a b c d :: int
assumes h0 : "a \<noteq> b \<and> a \<noteq> c \<and> a \<noteq> d \<and> b \<noteq> c \<and> b \<noteq> d \<and> c \<noteq> d"
and h1 : "\<exists>pairs. distinct pairs \<and> 
                (\<forall>(x, y) \<in> set pairs. x + y = 10 \<or> x + y = 18 \<or> x + y = 19 \<or> x + y = 20 \<or> x + y = 21 \<or> x + y = 29) \<and> 
                {a, b, c, d} = {fst p |p. p \<in> set pairs} \<union> {snd p |p. p \<in> set pairs}"
shows  "sorted_list_of_set {a, b, c, d} = [4, 6, 14, 15]"
a_5.formal solution:
(* ### Problem
 Four distinct integers $a$, $b$, $c$ and $d$ have the property that when added in pairs, the sums 10, 18, 19, 20, 21, and 29 are obtained. What are the four integers in increasing order? (place a comma and then a space between each integer) The final Answer is 4,6,14,15
 ### Proof
 WLOG, let $a<b<c<d$. The smallest sum is $a+b=10$. The second-smallest sum is $a+c=18$. The second-largest sum is $b+d=21$. The largest sum is $c+d=29$. In summary, \begin{align}\tag{1} a+b&=10\\ \tag{2}
 a+c&=18\\ \tag{3} b+d&=21\\ \tag{4} c+d&=29 \end{align} There are two sums left, $a+d$ and $b+c$.
 We will break this problem into two cases, the first case in which the first of the two sums is smaller than the second, and the second case in which the first of the two sums is larger than the second.
 In the first case \begin{align} \tag{5} a+d&=19\\ \tag{6} b+c&=20 \end{align} Adding Equations (1) and (6) and subtracting (2), we have $(a+b)+(b+c)-(a+c)=10+20-18\Rightarrow b = 6$. Plugging this value into Equation (1), we find that $a+6=10 \Rightarrow a=4$.
 Plugging the value of $a$ into Equation (2), we find that $4+c=18 \Rightarrow c=14$. Plugging the value of $c$ into Equation (4), we find that $14+d=29 \Rightarrow d=15$.
 Thus, the four integers are $4,6,14,15$. In the second case, \begin{align} \tag{7} b+c&=19\\ \tag{8} a+d&=20 \end{align} Adding Equations (1) and (7) and subtracting Equation (2), we have $(a+b)+(b+c)-(a+c)=10+19-18 \Rightarrow b=5.5$.
 This case is impossible because $b$ is defined to be an integer.
 Thus, the only solution is $\boxed{4,6,14,15}$.
 *)

theorem
fixes a b c d :: int
assumes h0 : "a \<noteq> b \<and> a \<noteq> c \<and> a \<noteq> d \<and> b \<noteq> c \<and> b \<noteq> d \<and> c \<noteq> d"
and h1 : "\<exists>pairs. distinct pairs \<and> 
                (\<forall>(x, y) \<in> set pairs. x + y = 10 \<or> x + y = 18 \<or> x + y = 19 \<or> x + y = 20 \<or> x + y = 21 \<or> x + y = 29) \<and> 
                {a, b, c, d} = {fst p |p. p \<in> set pairs} \<union> {snd p |p. p \<in> set pairs}"
shows  "sorted_list_of_set {a, b, c, d} = [4, 6, 14, 15]"
 proof- 
  show ?thesis sledgehammer
a_5.informal problem: There are four distinct integers, $a$, $b$, $c$, and $d$, which form a set of pairs such that the sum of the integers in each pair is one of the following numbers: 10, 18, 19, 20, 21, or 29. Find the values of $a$, $b$, $c$, and $d$. The final answer is $a = 4$, $b = 6$, $c = 14$, and $d = 15$.

a_6.formal problem:
theorem
fixes a b c d :: int
assumes h0 : "a \<noteq> b"
and h1 : "a \<noteq> c"
and h2 : "a \<noteq> d"
and h3 : "b \<noteq> c"
and h4 : "b \<noteq> d"
and h5 : "c \<noteq> d"
and h6 : "finite ({a+b, a+c, a+d, b+c, b+d, c+d} :: int set)"
and h7 : "sum id {a+b, a+c, a+d, b+c, b+d, c+d} = 10 + 18 + 19 + 20 + 21 + 29"
and h8 : "sorted [a, b, c, d]"
shows  "a = 4 \<and> b = 6 \<and> c = 14 \<and> d = 15"
a_6.formal solution:
(* ### Problem
 Four distinct integers $a$, $b$, $c$ and $d$ have the property that when added in pairs, the sums 10, 18, 19, 20, 21, and 29 are obtained. What are the four integers in increasing order? (place a comma and then a space between each integer) The final Answer is 4,6,14,15
 ### Proof
 WLOG, let $a<b<c<d$. The smallest sum is $a+b=10$. The second-smallest sum is $a+c=18$. The second-largest sum is $b+d=21$. The largest sum is $c+d=29$. In summary, \begin{align}\tag{1} a+b&=10\\ \tag{2}
 a+c&=18\\ \tag{3} b+d&=21\\ \tag{4} c+d&=29 \end{align} There are two sums left, $a+d$ and $b+c$.
 We will break this problem into two cases, the first case in which the first of the two sums is smaller than the second, and the second case in which the first of the two sums is larger than the second.
 In the first case \begin{align} \tag{5} a+d&=19\\ \tag{6} b+c&=20 \end{align} Adding Equations (1) and (6) and subtracting (2), we have $(a+b)+(b+c)-(a+c)=10+20-18\Rightarrow b = 6$. Plugging this value into Equation (1), we find that $a+6=10 \Rightarrow a=4$.
 Plugging the value of $a$ into Equation (2), we find that $4+c=18 \Rightarrow c=14$. Plugging the value of $c$ into Equation (4), we find that $14+d=29 \Rightarrow d=15$.
 Thus, the four integers are $4,6,14,15$. In the second case, \begin{align} \tag{7} b+c&=19\\ \tag{8} a+d&=20 \end{align} Adding Equations (1) and (7) and subtracting Equation (2), we have $(a+b)+(b+c)-(a+c)=10+19-18 \Rightarrow b=5.5$.
 This case is impossible because $b$ is defined to be an integer.
 Thus, the only solution is $\boxed{4,6,14,15}$.
 *)

theorem
fixes a b c d :: int
assumes h0 : "a \<noteq> b"
and h1 : "a \<noteq> c"
and h2 : "a \<noteq> d"
and h3 : "b \<noteq> c"
and h4 : "b \<noteq> d"
and h5 : "c \<noteq> d"
and h6 : "finite ({a+b, a+c, a+d, b+c, b+d, c+d} :: int set)"
and h7 : "sum id {a+b, a+c, a+d, b+c, b+d, c+d} = 10 + 18 + 19 + 20 + 21 + 29"
and h8 : "sorted [a, b, c, d]"
shows  "a = 4 \<and> b = 6 \<and> c = 14 \<and> d = 15"
 proof- 
  show ?thesis sledgehammer
a_6.informal problem: Four distinct integers a, b, c, and d are such that the sum of each of the six possible pairs is unique and finite. The sums are 10, 18, 19, 20, 21, and 29. Find the values of a, b, c, and d, given that they are in ascending order. The final answer is a = 4, b = 6, c = 14, and d = 15.

theorem
fixes a b c d :: int
assumes h0 : "distinct [a, b, c, d]"
and h1 : "{a + b, a + c, a + d, b + c, b + d, c + d} = {10, 18, 19, 20, 21, 29}"
shows  "sorted [a, b, c, d] \<and> [a, b, c, d] = [4, 6, 14, 15]"

a_8.formal problem:
theorem
fixes a b c d :: int
assumes h0 : "distinct [a, b, c, d]"
and h1 : "set [(a+b), (a+c), (a+d), (b+c), (b+d), (c+d)] = {10, 18, 19, 20, 21, 29}"
shows  "sorted [a, b, c, d] \<and> [a, b, c, d] = [4, 6, 14, 15]"
a_8.formal solution:
(* ### Problem
 Four distinct integers $a$, $b$, $c$ and $d$ have the property that when added in pairs, the sums 10, 18, 19, 20, 21, and 29 are obtained. What are the four integers in increasing order? (place a comma and then a space between each integer) The final Answer is 4,6,14,15
 ### Proof
 WLOG, let $a<b<c<d$. The smallest sum is $a+b=10$. The second-smallest sum is $a+c=18$. The second-largest sum is $b+d=21$. The largest sum is $c+d=29$. In summary, \begin{align}\tag{1} a+b&=10\\ \tag{2}
 a+c&=18\\ \tag{3} b+d&=21\\ \tag{4} c+d&=29 \end{align} There are two sums left, $a+d$ and $b+c$.
 We will break this problem into two cases, the first case in which the first of the two sums is smaller than the second, and the second case in which the first of the two sums is larger than the second.
 In the first case \begin{align} \tag{5} a+d&=19\\ \tag{6} b+c&=20 \end{align} Adding Equations (1) and (6) and subtracting (2), we have $(a+b)+(b+c)-(a+c)=10+20-18\Rightarrow b = 6$. Plugging this value into Equation (1), we find that $a+6=10 \Rightarrow a=4$.
 Plugging the value of $a$ into Equation (2), we find that $4+c=18 \Rightarrow c=14$. Plugging the value of $c$ into Equation (4), we find that $14+d=29 \Rightarrow d=15$.
 Thus, the four integers are $4,6,14,15$. In the second case, \begin{align} \tag{7} b+c&=19\\ \tag{8} a+d&=20 \end{align} Adding Equations (1) and (7) and subtracting Equation (2), we have $(a+b)+(b+c)-(a+c)=10+19-18 \Rightarrow b=5.5$.
 This case is impossible because $b$ is defined to be an integer.
 Thus, the only solution is $\boxed{4,6,14,15}$.
 *)

theorem
fixes a b c d :: int
assumes h0 : "distinct [a, b, c, d]"
and h1 : "set [(a+b), (a+c), (a+d), (b+c), (b+d), (c+d)] = {10, 18, 19, 20, 21, 29}"
shows  "sorted [a, b, c, d] \<and> [a, b, c, d] = [4, 6, 14, 15]"
 proof- 
  show ?thesis sledgehammer
a_8.informal problem: Four distinct integers, $a$, $b$, $c$, and $d$, have the property that their pairwise sums, $(a+b)$, $(a+c)$, $(a+d)$, $(b+c)$, $(b+d)$, and $(c+d)$, are equal to $10$, $18$, $19$, $20$, $21$, and $29$. Find the values of $a$, $b$, $c$, and $d$. The final answer is $4$, $6$, $14$, and $15$.

a_9.formal problem:
theorem
fixes a b c d :: int
assumes h0 : "distinct [a, b, c, d]"
and h1 : "{a + b, a + c, a + d, b + c, b + d, c + d} = {10, 18, 19, 20, 21, 29}"
shows  "sorted [a, b, c, d] \<and> a = 4 \<and> b = 6 \<and> c = 14 \<and> d = 15"
a_9.formal solution:
(* ### Problem
 Four distinct integers $a$, $b$, $c$ and $d$ have the property that when added in pairs, the sums 10, 18, 19, 20, 21, and 29 are obtained. What are the four integers in increasing order? (place a comma and then a space between each integer) The final Answer is 4,6,14,15
 ### Proof
 WLOG, let $a<b<c<d$. The smallest sum is $a+b=10$. The second-smallest sum is $a+c=18$. The second-largest sum is $b+d=21$. The largest sum is $c+d=29$. In summary, \begin{align}\tag{1} a+b&=10\\ \tag{2}
 a+c&=18\\ \tag{3} b+d&=21\\ \tag{4} c+d&=29 \end{align} There are two sums left, $a+d$ and $b+c$.
 We will break this problem into two cases, the first case in which the first of the two sums is smaller than the second, and the second case in which the first of the two sums is larger than the second.
 In the first case \begin{align} \tag{5} a+d&=19\\ \tag{6} b+c&=20 \end{align} Adding Equations (1) and (6) and subtracting (2), we have $(a+b)+(b+c)-(a+c)=10+20-18\Rightarrow b = 6$. Plugging this value into Equation (1), we find that $a+6=10 \Rightarrow a=4$.
 Plugging the value of $a$ into Equation (2), we find that $4+c=18 \Rightarrow c=14$. Plugging the value of $c$ into Equation (4), we find that $14+d=29 \Rightarrow d=15$.
 Thus, the four integers are $4,6,14,15$. In the second case, \begin{align} \tag{7} b+c&=19\\ \tag{8} a+d&=20 \end{align} Adding Equations (1) and (7) and subtracting Equation (2), we have $(a+b)+(b+c)-(a+c)=10+19-18 \Rightarrow b=5.5$.
 This case is impossible because $b$ is defined to be an integer.
 Thus, the only solution is $\boxed{4,6,14,15}$.
 *)

theorem
fixes a b c d :: int
assumes h0 : "distinct [a, b, c, d]"
and h1 : "{a + b, a + c, a + d, b + c, b + d, c + d} = {10, 18, 19, 20, 21, 29}"
shows  "sorted [a, b, c, d] \<and> a = 4 \<and> b = 6 \<and> c = 14 \<and> d = 15"
 proof- 
  show ?thesis sledgehammer
a_9.informal problem: Four distinct integers $a, b, c, d$ have the property that their sums in pairs are $10, 18, 19, 20, 21, 29$. Find the integers $a, b, c, d$ in ascending order. The final answer is $a=4$, $b=6$, $c=14$, and $d=15$.

natural problem: Four distinct integers $a$, $b$, $c$ and $d$ have the property that when added in pairs, the sums 10, 18, 19, 20, 21, and 29 are obtained. What are the four integers in increasing order? (place a comma and then a space between each integer)
natural solution: WLOG, let $a<b<c<d$. The smallest sum is $a+b=10$. The second-smallest sum is $a+c=18$. The second-largest sum is $b+d=21$. The largest sum is $c+d=29$. In summary, \begin{align}\tag{1} a+b&=10\\ \tag{2}
a+c&=18\\ \tag{3} b+d&=21\\ \tag{4} c+d&=29 \end{align} There are two sums left, $a+d$ and $b+c$.

We will break this problem into two cases, the first case in which the first of the two sums is smaller than the second, and the second case in which the first of the two sums is larger than the second.

In the first case \begin{align} \tag{5} a+d&=19\\ \tag{6} b+c&=20 \end{align} Adding Equations (1) and (6) and subtracting (2), we have $(a+b)+(b+c)-(a+c)=10+20-18\Rightarrow b = 6$. Plugging this value into Equation (1), we find that $a+6=10 \Rightarrow a=4$.
Plugging the value of $a$ into Equation (2), we find that $4+c=18 \Rightarrow c=14$. Plugging the value of $c$ into Equation (4), we find that $14+d=29 \Rightarrow d=15$.

Thus, the four integers are $4,6,14,15$. In the second case, \begin{align} \tag{7} b+c&=19\\ \tag{8} a+d&=20 \end{align} Adding Equations (1) and (7) and subtracting Equation (2), we have $(a+b)+(b+c)-(a+c)=10+19-18 \Rightarrow b=5.5$.
This case is impossible because $b$ is defined to be an integer.
